title: An important next step on our AI journey

last_post.content:
Google used to take pride in minimizing time we spent there, guiding us to relevant pages as quickly as possible. Over time, they tried to answer everything themselves: longer snippets, inline FAQs, search results full of knowledge panels.

Today's Bard announcement feels like their natural evolution: extracting all value out of the internet for themselves, burying pages at the bottom of each GPT-generated essay like footnotes. https://blog.google/technology/ai/bard-google-ai-search-updates/
NASA is hiring a Chief Data Officer. I'll bet a few of you know someone who absolutely needs to know about this opportunity: https://www.usajobs.gov/job/700799600

Interesting read. I have had a gut feeling for years now that the modern frontend world is way more complex than it needs to be. When I used server side rendering and mostly html/CSS and a little js here and there for a widget, things were fast to develop and fast to use. Compared to the js-heavy stacks we are used to, this was remarkable.

https://infrequently.org/2023/02/the-market-for-lemons/

Different every time. Excellent.
https://www.monkeon.co.uk/gifaanisqatsi/

StreetPass is a cool new browser extension that uses Mastodon's verification system in a clever way.

Mastodon users verify themselves by adding a custom link to their personal site. StreetPass lets you know when you've found one of these links, and adds them to your list. As you browse the web, StreetPass will build a list of Mastodon users that belong to the websites you visit.

I spoke with the creater @tvler about the project, 🧵 below.

Visit https://streetpass.social/ to try it yourself!

is calling on Twitter to alter their decision and let the research community still have free access to the data they need: https://independenttechresearch.org/letter-twitter-api-access-threatens-public-interest-research/

Hey folks, TootSDK is now public! 🚀

TootSDK is a Swift package for creating apps that interact with Mastodon, Pleroma and other Fediverse APIs.

It handles the data model and network calls, with lovely async/await based calls.

The SDK is still young. There are plenty of API calls still to add. The foundations are strong, and TootSDK is very useful already.

Contributions and PRs are more than welcome!

Check out the repo here: https://github.com/tootsdk/tootsdk :mastodance: :apple:

#swift #iosdev #vapor #serversideswift #appkit #uikit #swiftui

"We don’t often talk about “convenience” when we talk about data privacy, but we should. In the game of personal-data gathering, convenience is the bait. title: Myspace loses all content uploaded before 2016

last_post.content:
Reminder that whatever you store on an internet site will one day vanish, even if it's stored on the largest and richest site in the world:

"Myspace, the once mighty social network, has lost every single piece of content uploaded to its site before 2016, including millions of songs, photos and videos with no other home on the internet."

https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/mar/18/myspace-loses-all-content-uploaded-before-2016

Please don't rely on internet services to exist forever, they will all disappear eventually.

Try to store copies of important stuff offline if you can. Music, video, photos etc can all be stored locally.

title: Voices in the Code: Algorithms, People and Values

last_post.content:
New podcast!

Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia University research director Katy Glenn Bass hosted a conversation based on themes from David G. Robinson’s first book, Voices in the Code, featuring Robinson, Deborah Raji and J. Nathan Matias.

The book bears insights on how algorithmic systems that are often heavily freighted with moral and political complexity can and should be developed with care to avoid excluding the voices of non-technical stakeholders.
https://techpolicy.press/voices-in-the-code-algorithms-people-and-values/

title: Sam Harris | #310 - Social Media & Public Trust

last_post.content:
I went on the Sam Harris Podcast w/Bari Weiss & Michael Shellenberger - two journos who worked on the Twitter files - to talk ab social media & public trust. Some of the convo was ab findings- different interpretations of Files stories -but much was ab loss of trust in institutions. We talked ab “Russiagate”, the role of the govt (FBI & CDC talking to platforms?), the infamous 💻, & the need for transparency.

https://www.samharris.org/podcasts/making-sense-episodes/310-social-media-public-trust

title: Cosmic Threads: A Solar System Quilt from 1876

last_post.content:
In the autumn of 1883, a paper in the nation's capital reported that "an Iowa woman has spent 7 years embroidering the solar system on a quilt."

Ellen Harding Baker used her stunning quilt to teach astronomy in an era when women could not attend college:
https://www.themarginalian.org/2018/12/06/ellen-harding-baker-solar-system-quilt/

A brief #introduction: I'm a data scientist w/ a math+stats background. I've been with the Wikimedia Foundation (the non-profit behind Wikipedia) for 7y+ and I've been managing since 2021

You may have read my guide on hiring: https://magazine.amstat.org/blog/2018/09/01/hiring-a-data-scientist/

I’ve written about my journey as an individual contributor (back in 2017) on my blog: https://mpopov.com/blog/2017/09/21/the-journey-so-far/

I've authored a few R packages, most notably WikidataQueryServiceR

You can learn about my team and what we do at https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Product_Analytics

📢 In a recent report, Microsoft Digital Threat Analysis Center (DTAC) attributes a recent influence operation targeting French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo to an Iranian nation-state actor, NEPTUNIUM.

💧 In January, a hacker group known as "Holy Souls" claimed to have obtained the personal information of over 200,000 Charlie Hebdo customers. They released a sample of the data, which included full names, telephone numbers, and email and home addresses, putting subscribers at risk of targeting by extremist organizations.

🛡️ To help against these influence operations, DTAC also released their Influence Attribution Framework. This tool helps organizations understand, attribute, and mitigate the impact of these operations. For more information on how the framework works, I've put together a simple infographic that summarizes its key components. 👇 #microsoft #threatintelligence #influence #infosec #cybersecurity #microsoftsecurity

📰 Report: https://lnkd.in/gwp7Aq9m

⚙ Framework: https://lnkd.in/gVuv6D8S

Survey of 14 research articles published in Psychological Science finds:

@akkartik Thanks! the sand's behaviour is defined in 129-154 here: https://github.com/TodePond/SandLab/blob/a9eb111917b35553758b42d28978f68f8a5e6894/source/element.js#L128

If the sand can 'move' down, it moves down.

Otherwise, if it's bigger than the minimum size, it tries to split into 2 cells (above and below), and the above cell tries to move sideways.

Otherwise, it tries to merge with a nearby sand cell.

So, yes! the fine cells merge back bigger when they can't move.

title: GitHub - samim23/polymath: Convert any music library into a music production sample-library with ML

last_post.content:
Wow! @jesse just hipped me to this amazing bit of #demix/#remix #AI #ML #music #python tech called Polymath.

"The tool automatically separates songs into stems (beats, bass, etc.), quantizes them to the same tempo and beat-grid (e.g. 120bpm) and analyzes musical structure, key (e.g C4, E3, etc.) and other infos (timbre, loudness, etc.). The result is a searchable sample library that streamlines the workflow for music producers, DJs, and ML audio developers."

https://github.com/samim23/polymath

title: Developing a globally fair pricing model for Open Access academic publishing | Plan S

last_post.content:
Plum job: "#cOAlition_S wishes to commission a study…to identify ways in which readers and producers of scholarly publications (or their proxies, namely research #funders and #universities) could financially contribute to supporting the academic publishing services valued by their research communities as a function of their means in a manner that is globally equitable and sustainable."
https://www.coalition-s.org/developing-a-globally-fair-pricing-model-for-open-access-academic-publishing/

If you want to undertake the study, apply before March 13.

#jobs #OpenAccess

title: Coming soon: Shift Happens: A book about keyboards

last_post.content:
Shift Happens — @mwichary’s book about the history of keyboards — is now live on Kickstarter!

I’ve been enjoying an early preview test print and can say it’s beautiful. I’ve always loved Marcin’s writing and attention to detail in typography, but this book sets a new bar. There is so much care in his typesetting and amazing depth in his photographs. I can’t wait to see read the final book.

Don’t miss out! https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/mwichary/shift-happens
